baseline completion: to replace longtime ally Alberto Gonzales, who resigned in September. The nomination had been considered at risk after a number of Democratic senators opposed Mukasey because of questions that arose from his views on the terror interrogation technique known as waterboarding and the president's power to order electronic surveillance. Mukasey's confirmation was all but assured last week when two key Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee -- Sens. Dianne Feinstein of California and Chuck Schumer of New York -- said they would vote in favor of Mukasey despite the controversy. original watermarked completion:
Orme.

In the past year, the fire, damage and water delivery has drained about a quarter of the town's budget. The school district has seen a loss of more than $400,000.

In recent months, a 16-year-old girl, April, was killed in Orme and a police officer was wounded after they were fired at while confronting a car on W.C. Davis Parkway.

The Orme town council is facing a $3 million deficit.

"We've got firefighters coming from all over the state," Winters said. "They come from the south. They come from the north. And they've been dropping water

baseline completion: Orme, Tennessee. The mountain spring that supplies water to the town usually dries up at the end of summer, but just for a few days. This year it dried up early, on August 1, and hasn't revived, leaving the town's 145 residents high and dry and relying on water trucked in from the next state. Every day at 6 p.m., Orme Mayor Tony Reames turns a big valve to release water from the town's tank. When he turns the crank again at 9 p.m., taps in the town run dry. "When they cut it back on we jump for joy," Orme resident Debbie Cash said. "And then you only have it for three hours." Three hours to do all the laundry, bathing, dishwashing and animal watering that has to be done.  Watch how Cash copes » . The old mining town could be the canary in the coal mine for the rest of the region. Just 150 miles to the southeast,

"When they cut it back on we jump for joy," Orme resident Debbie Cash said. "And then you only have it for three hours." Three hours to do all the laundry, bathing, dishwashing and animal watering that has to be done.  Watch how Cash copes » . The old mining town could be the canary in the coal mine for the rest of the region. Just 150 miles to the southeast,

The refugees, already in camps after fleeing the violence in neighboring Rwanda, moved north toward Rwanda, the U.N. refugee agency said. Many of the new refugees were from the nearby Lakes region.

The United Nations says the new fighting started Tuesday in the area around the border with Rwanda.

The government reported fighting in central Kivu province, where Goma is located. The province is also home to the massive Kongo River port that is a key source of foreign aid to the country.

Hitchcock was, without question, one of the towering geniuses of cinema. And, like many greats, he wasn't exactly the best collaborator. Hitchcock was particularly trying for screenwriters, who felt he never properly credited them for their work. But he was notoriously hard on actors. He was once quoted as saying, "Actors are cattle" -- a quip that stirred up a huge outcry (actors can be so touchy). In response, he issued this correction: "I have been misquoted. What I really said is, 'Actors should be treated as cattle.'" In a posting on an Islamist Web site, the group al Qaeda Islamic Maghreb claimed responsibility. prompt: BAGHDAD, Iraq (CNN) -- None of the 1,000-plus Iraqi detainees freed in recent weeks have broken a pledge not to return to the insurgency, according to the Marine general who oversees the U.S. detention centers in Iraq. A U.S. military panel reviews a detainee's
original watermarked completion:
behavior and determines whether they're fit for release. But there is no guarantee that those detainees, including a former Marine, could be rehabilitated.

The release of the detainees was large but not unexpected. It was an effort by President Bush, as the country's military was reeling, to show that he was committed to winding down the war in Iraq.

The Pentagon released a report Tuesday showing that since Sept. 11, the U.S. military has released 6,564 detainees, including 1,931 in the last two weeks.

The Pentagon releases only information of detainees without legal representation, and the military panel overseeing the detainees' release reviews the inmates' behavior.

But that panel cannot determine whether a detainee would be rehabilitated.

The Pentagon agreed to let the panel review the behavior and work with the United Nations to determine whether a detainee might be returned to combat, said Maj. Gen. Charles O. Jones Jr., head of the Joint Staff

Doug Stone on Wednesday reassured Iraqis about how the 25,000 detainees -- mostly Sunnis -- are treated after being taken into custody on suspicion of involvement in the insurgency. Stone described the detention system as "open and transparent," saying it makes the detainees better citizens and helps break the cycle of violence and poverty in the country. Stone said detainees get free medical care equal to what he gets as a general, food and water made to Islamic standards, educational opportunities, jobs skills and contact with families. The U.S. detention centers -- at Camp Bucca near the southern port city of Basra and in Camp Cropper near Baghdad -- are political sore points for Sunnis, who make up 83 percent of the detainees held. baseline completion: case at Camp Cropper near Baghdad. Speaking in Arabic, Maj. Gen. Doug Stone on Wednesday reassured Iraqis about how the 25,000 detainees -- mostly Sunnis -- are treated after being taken into custody on suspicion of involvement in the insurgency. Stone described the detention system as "open and transparent," saying it makes the detainees better citizens and helps break the cycle of violence and poverty in the country. Stone said detainees get free medical care equal to what he gets as a general, food and water made to Islamic standards, educational opportunities, jobs skills and contact with families. The U.S. detention centers -- at Camp Bucca near the southern port city of Basra and in Camp Cropper near Baghdad -- are political sore points for Sunnis, who make up 83 percent of the detainees held. The main Sunni political coalition -- the Iraqi Accord Front -- cited the centers as one reason for quitting the government during the summer. Last month, the U.S.-led coalition launched Operation Lion's Paw

prompt: BAGHDAD, Iraq (CNN) -- None of the 1,000-plus Iraqi detainees freed in recent weeks have broken a pledge not to return to the insurgency, according to the Marine general who oversees the U.S. detention centers in Iraq. A U.S. military panel reviews a detainee's
original watermarked completion:
behavior and determines whether they're fit for release. But there is no guarantee that those detainees, including a former Marine, could be rehabilitated.

The release of the detainees was large but not unexpected. It was an effort by President Bush, as the country's military was reeling, to show that he was committed to winding down the war in Iraq.

The Pentagon released a report Tuesday showing that since Sept. 11, the U.S. military has released 6,564 detainees, including 1,931 in the last two weeks.

The Pentagon releases only information of detainees without legal representation, and the military panel overseeing the detainees' release reviews the inmates' behavior.

But that panel cannot determine whether a detainee would be rehabilitated.

The Pentagon agreed to let the panel review the behavior and work with the United Nations to determine whether a detainee might be returned to combat, said Maj. Gen. Charles O. Jones Jr., head of the Joint Staff
